attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/ChadScherrer|@ChadScherrer>: My book recommendations for #Bayesian analysis:

• Kevin Murphy: <https://probml.github.io/pml-book/book1.html>

• David MacKay: <http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/>

• David Barber: <http://web4.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/D.Barber/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Brml.Online>

• Chris Bishop: <https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/uploads/prod/2006/01/Bishop-Pattern-Recognition-and-Machine-Learning-2006.pdf>

All free online. Of course buy them if you can afford it :slightly_smiling_face:

All free online. Of course buy them if you can afford it :slightly_smiling_face:

text: This is a nice list - would be good to have a copy of it kept somewhere outside the Slack memory hole

text: <@U81PB6N77> Do you mind if I cross-post the list to Discourse or Zulip? I don't use Twitter.

text:
BTW I love this comparison: "Comparison of Information Theory, Inference, and Learning Algorithms with Harry Potter"

<http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/Potter.html>

elements.text: BTW I love this comparison: "Comparison of Information Theory, Inference, and Learning Algorithms with Harry Potter"

text: I can't believe Harry Potter doesn't have any exercises. How are you supposed to use it as a course textbook?
